It must have been about 90 degrees that day at the Ohio Scottish Arts School as we sat, wedged into the tiny classroom, sweating and struggling to capture the tune our instructor was teaching us, by ear as always. Everybody else seemed to be picking it up pretty easily but I was definitely struggling. 

We played a little section of the tune and Steve said: “Is that a Butterfly or a Bowtie?” “Butterfly!” Someone called out. Steve, the kindest person I know, saw my blank, puzzled look, placed his fingers on D E G A and explained “ We call this position The Butterfly.” Wow! The lightbulb went on in my head and for the first time, I began to see these Celtic tunes as not a long string of notes to learn like a pianist, but as a few common patterns, one of which now had a cute name to help me remember it. As I thought about these common patterns, I realized that mastering a quite small group of them would be a big help in playing these Celtic tunes. 

So I wrote them down and started practicing them every day. Most brain research says it takes 300 to 500 repetitions of any pattern to get to the point of automatic correct response and sure enough, when I got to 300 repetitions, BINGO! I could play these positions anywhere very easily and automatically. It was wonderful! So that’s the magic I want you to have as well.
